definition-item.definition-title: SPINNING OR TWISTING (twisting oakum D01G35/00; crimping or curling of fibres, filaments, or yarns D02G1/00)

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
The spinning or twisting of staple fibre yarns (i.e. comprising fibres of discrete length); e.g. cotton or wool spinning.
This place does not cover:

table-column.paragraph-text: Twisting oakum
Crimping or curling of fibres, filaments or yarns

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Unwinding, paying-out, forwarding, winding or coiling filamentary material, not intimately associated with spinning or twisting
Cores, formers, supports or holders for coiled or wound material, e.g. bobbins
The formation of continuous synthetic filaments
D01D, D01F
Finishing or dressing of filaments, yarns, threads, cords, ropes, or the like
Chenille fabrics, making chenille trimmings by weaving
Chenille trimmings
Testing yarns, rovings, slivers, fibres or fibre webs

section-body.paragraph-text: In this place, the following terms or expressions are used with the meaning indicated:

table-column.paragraph-text: Fibre
A relatively-short, elongated member of natural or artificial material
Filament
An endless or quasi-endless, elongated member of natural (e.g. silk) or artificial material
Yarn
A unitary assembly of fibres, usually produced by spinning
Thread
An assembly of yarns or filaments, usually produced by twisting
Drawing
Stretching and elongating yarns or filaments
Draft
The amount to which yarns or filaments are drawn

definition-item.definition-title: Spinning or twisting machines in which the product is wound-up continuously (open-end spinning machines D01H4/00 {; doubling of yarns B65H54/00+T; doubled, plied or cabled threads D02G3/28, e.g. using hollow spindles D02G3/283; spin-twisting D02G3/281; threads with alternately "S" and "Z" direction of twist, e.g. self-twist process, D02G3/286; wrapping strands of filaments or staple fibres by a binder yarn D02G3/38})

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
the spinning processes where twist is inserted into a fibre strand, without interrupting the fibre strand.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: "open-end" technique, whereby the fibre strand is interrupted

definition-item.definition-title: {Twisting machines in which twist is imparted from the supply packages, e.g. uptwist}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
the cases where the supply package provides the twist.

definition-item.definition-title: {Twisting machines in which twist is imparted at the paying-out and take-up stations}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
the cases where twist comes from the collecting bobbin, and corresponds for example to ring spinning and similar processes.

definition-item.definition-title: ring type {(arrangements with two or more spinning or twisting devices in combination D01H7/90)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
a spinning process in which a yarn is twisted and wound onto a revolving bobbin surrounded by a ring that moves up-and down, and caries a traveller set in motion by the yarn.

definition-item.definition-title: flyer type

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
a spinning process in which a yarn (typically coarse woollen yarn) is twisted by a rotating flyer arm, that winds it onto a bobbin that is free to rotate.

definition-item.definition-title: cap type

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
a spinning process in which a yarn (typically woollen yarn) is twisted and wound onto a revolving bobbin situated inside a stationary cap.

definition-item.definition-title: cup, pot or disc type, in which annular masses of yarn are formed by centrifugal action

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
centrifugal spinning, where a yarn mass (or cake) is formed inside or on a rotating element, e.g. a pot, which at the same time imparts twist and collects the yarn.

definition-item.definition-title: for imparting multiple twist, e.g. two-for-one twisting

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
twisting of several yarns, whereby one spindle turn causes several twist turns in the assembled yarn (obtained e.g. by multiple yarn reversal points in the yarn run path).
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Cabling

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
spinning techniques like friction spinning or air jet spinning, provided there is no fibre flow interruption.

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

the spinning processes where twist is inserted into a fibre strand, whereby an interruption of the fibre strand takes place in order to insert twist; e.g. the fibres are taken out from the strand and blown into a rotor that turns at high speed.

definition-item.definition-title: Drafting machines or arrangements {; Threading of roving into drafting machine}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

Drafting machines as stand alone, as well as drafting arrangements in spinning machines. Slivers are drafted into slivers, rovings or fibre strands by the action of progressively accelerating drafting cylinders.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: After drafting and before spinning

Increasing the strength of a roving or sliver by false-twisting

definition-item.definition-title: Gill boxes or other drafting machines employing fallers or like pinned bars

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

Drafting machines having fibre control arrangements placed between the drafting cylinders; said control elements are pinned bars. The machines themselves are called gill boxes, and are used in long staple (i.e. wool, flax) spinning preparation.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Lubricating fibres in gill boxes
